PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Gareth Evans. Why didn't you, as foreign minister, act immediately after the French presidential victory to seek to dissuade the new administration from its election commitment to resume nuclear testing in the Pacific? Why didn't you lead a delegation at that time rather than after the public announcement when you knew it would be much more difficult to influence a change? And, after the announcement, why did you play down the decision with your statement that it was not as bad as it might have been, which you knew was code for telling the French that you were simply going through the motions of protest? How did you get it all so wrong?

—We did act to dissuade the French as best we possibly could. In the period immediately after the election and before an announcement was made on nuclear tests, the Prime Minister wrote to President Chirac in very explicit terms; I wrote to Juppe, the former foreign minister, now Prime Minister; and it was made very clear to them what our position on the basic issues of principle was.

PARA.TAB: When it came to the decision actually being made, there was no question as to the reality of the feeling of both me and the Australian government in this respect. I have to say that, personally, I was extremely upset at the way in which the French government had breached faith with the international community in the context of the NPT negotiations. Only one month previously, in one of the hardest fought diplomatic exercises that Australia has ever mounted, we managed to get international support for the indefinite extension of that treaty. We did so, among other things, on the basis of the nuclear weapons states agreeing to exercise the utmost restraint so far as nuclear tests were concerned, and the French government, within barely a month after that, manifestly acted in breach of that commitment.

Secondly, I was extremely upset at the implications of this for the CTBT, the comprehensive test ban negotiations, because of the implications, again, of the French decision for the course of those negotiations, which has been a very long, hard-fought-for Australian policy position. The dangers of polarising the environment in Geneva, the dangers of creating an impossible negotiating situation in relation to some of those outstanding sensitive issues, are very real. Thirdly, I and the government generally, like the Australian people, were deeply upset with that aspect of the French decision, which involved once again, with supreme and contemptuous disregard for the interests of the people of the South Pacific region—

TALK.START.PARA: —All too late, Gareth.

—I will come to this. It involved, with that sort of disregard for the people of the South Pacific region, after a break of three years which had won the French widespread respect and credibility around the region, their once again determining to go ahead, albeit on a limited basis.

PARA.TAB: The question was: how was that anger, which was very real and very genuine, to be translated into a diplomatically effective response? That is the particular problem that we have been wrestling with. It is very easy in this kind of context to express yourself in extremely voluble, over-the-top terms without regard to the implications of that for a capacity to actually change the situation for the better in the longer run.

What we in the government decided upon was a controlled response building up over time, with these following elements. Step one would be a relatively clear-cut but nonetheless modulated response which would make it clear that the French behaviour was utterly deplorable and to be condemned, and would spell out why that was the case but would at the same time create a basis for a further exercise in persuasion being mounted in a way that would not be counterproductive. Secondly, it would involve consultation with the South Pacific countries with a view to developing a combined regional response. We put that in place very quickly—within two, three, four days of the announcement—with the delegation to France. Thirdly, it involved follow-up action after that particular delegation had its opportunity to seek to persuade the French government and to get a response. That follow-up action is exactly what we are now embarked upon. There will be follow-up at a Forum-wide regional level. There will be further follow-up of an appropriate kind at the Australian government level. I will be putting a package of measures to the government later today which will do just that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister has missed the point. Before I get to the nub of it, in the last few days we have been told that you did write to the French Prime Minister. Then we were told in this place that you did not write to the French Prime Minister. Today you tell us that you did write to the French Prime Minister. I invite you to table that letter so that we can all have a look at it. Your modulated response seemed to be so much inaction. Why did you not lead a delegation and do more than write a letter before the decision was announced, when there was some real chance of influencing a policy change? Why leave it all until after the announcement and why, after the announcement, play it down? Surely that is a modulated response that can only tell the French that we are really not serious about protest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know why I would ever be minded to ever take any notice of John Howard about anything. But let me just remind you of what John Howard's initial response was on the very first day. Last week Mr Howard said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . some times in these matters what you should do is give an initial response and if that doesn't produce any result, then you might consider a further response and it's never smart in those situations to fire all your shots at once.

That was exactly the position we adopted. We made very clear how much we deplored and condemned the situation, for all the reasons that I have just spelt out. We made very clear that we were engaged in an exercise in persuasion, not a mere futile Alexander Downer type adolescent protest. To make that persuasion effective, we believed it was necessary to acknowledge whatever it was that could be said by the other side. We then upped the ante by mounting a mission to Paris. Because that particular mission failed to produce the result, as it has, we are now proposing to take further steps. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: International Forum on the Indian Ocean Region

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. I refer to the recent international forum on the Indian Ocean region, held in Perth, and the mixed media comment arising from it. Can you inform the Senate of what was achieved from the forum and whether it met government expectations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government has been very confident since the conclusion of the Indian Ocean region forum that it was a success because it met the goals we set. But it is always more effective when you get the assessment of people other than yourself for something that you have undertaken. Let me indicate two or three of the responses that we have had to the outcome of the forum. Most particularly, yesterday I had the opportunity of talking to the Indian Minister of State for External Affairs, Mr Khur Shid. During my discussions with him last night, he made it absolutely clear that, in his view, the forum was a success in achieving goals which we share. They were the goals of having, for the first time, an inclusive gathering to discuss cooperation in the Indian Ocean region, to get the discussion going and to set up processes which will enable us to take forward regional cooperation, to elicit ideas on how we might move forward and to develop a process for doing it. They were our objectives, and they were met.

PARA.TAB: We saw two regional bodies established—the Indian Ocean consultative business network and the Indian Ocean research network. They are both scheduled to meet in New Delhi in December next year. It is very easy for people, including some members of the opposition, to say that this was not a sufficient achievement and that somehow or other we should therefore consider it a failure. I refer to the two recently published responses by participants, not members of the government, and in one instance someone not even known to me, but people who have indicated their view of the response. Firstly, I refer to a response from Harold Clough, the president of ACCI, in a letter published in the Australian Financial Review on 21 June. He described the forum as a landmark event in world trade and commerce and said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . there can be little doubt an IOECC, or an equivalent, will be formed in the near future.
. . . there is widespread support for a vehicle like an IOECC to improve commercial and economic relations in this region, and the Perth meeting was considered by all to have been a great success.
Mr Clough chaired the meetings of business people at that forum, so he was the person best placed to judge the mood, rather than some of those who sat in Wagga and made clever remarks.

PARA.TAB: Then there was a lengthy article by a fellow from the Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies at the ANU, Sandy Gordon, whom I have not had the opportunity to discuss this with. That contribution by Dr Gordon comments upon the considerable potential of the liberalising of the economy of South Asia and says:

ANSWER.PARA: As for the conference itself, the fact that no cooperative structure emerged does not mean there was no momentum towards regionalism. In fact, there was a general consensus that the process should be taken forward, make certain comparisons with APEC.

It was suggested within the security workshop, for example, that an interinstitutional dialogue process be initiated. Such a process, if properly supported, could potentially lead to a genuine second track dialogue emerging, a goal that has hitherto alluded the region.

So it met the goals that the government set and they are goals that are very important for Australia. It is a pity that some people tried to interpret it as not being a success because that undermines our opportunity to build on the momentum we have created. I believe the meetings that will happen in Delhi in December and subsequent activity and the meeting in Mauritius in August and what flows from it if it is as successful as the Perth one, will mean that we have a momentum for Indian Ocean cooperation that will be substantially to the economic and diplomatic benefit of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Gareth Gareth-Evans. Isn't it true that your pathetically feeble pussy cat response to the French government is a direct reflection of the fact that it is an important voting member of the Security Council?
—Ask a serious question.

—This is very serious; it goes to the heart of government responsibility. Isn't this a classic example of the conflict of interest that inevitably arises when personal ambition and the need to cultivate key countries get in the way of your duty to stand up strongly for Australian interests? Despite the fact that in your absence you were comprehensively rebuffed by Senator Robert Ray in your House of Representatives leadership ambitions, will you now give an unequivocal assurance that you will publicly renounce your international ambitions and concentrate exclusively on your portfolio responsibilities?

—What you see with me is what you get and what you get from me is frank, direct and robust representations on matters that go to vital national Australian interests and vital matters of international concern. What you don't get from me is a press release lion and a face to face mouse, which is exactly what you get from Alexander Downer. If you remember, the very first day that he was appointed foreign affairs spokesman he put out a press release saying what a hero he had been in raising human rights issues with the Vietnamese foreign minister. Two hours later the Vietnamese foreign minister and the embassy put out their own press release saying he had not even raised the issue at all, yet he put out a press release claiming that. This is the sort of nonsense we have to put up with from the other side of politics.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that in all my representations to the French government—face to face with Alain Juppe, two days before the election in Bordeaux, and across the table in the Quai d'Orsay with the French Foreign Minister, Herve de Charette, two nights ago—what you had from me was a full, frank, direct, robust, forceful, unequivocal and unambiguous presentation of everything that was wrong with the French decision and why that decision needed to be revisited and how it needed to be qualified and developed over time.

In order to be effective in mounting those representations, you have to pay due regard to the way in which international discourse works and the necessity not to fire every shot in your locker and anticipate every course of action you will subsequently take before you do it; because if you ignore, in your public statements, whatever it is—however minute—that can be said for the other side's argument, all that happens is that when you confront those on the other side with your position, they spend all their time talking back at you about what you have ignored in your initial presentation. That is a fact of life. That is what I took into account in working out how best to set the ground for a substantial, effective, very frank and very direct face to face confrontation—which is exactly what occurred two nights ago.

The New Zealanders were there; the other Pacific island countries were there; and all of them were totally happy, relaxed and confident about the way the thing was handled and believed it was very much an exercise in South Pacific regional interests, as well as acknowledging that this was entirely consistent with Australia's national interest.

In the entire time I have been this country's foreign minister—and this will continue to be the case into the future—it is inconceivable that any consideration would wage impact upon me other than the most effective, most persuasive and most credible way, in terms of the normal courtesies of international discourse, of mounting a case in Australia's interests. That is what I am about and that is why it is that Australian foreign policy and Australia's international reputation at the moment stand higher than they ever have in this country's history; because of the way in which we have systematically and effectively presented what it is that we are about in a way that is consistent with Australia's security and economic interests and Australia's responsibilities as a good international citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested to hear the minister confess that what you see is what you get, because what we see is someone running around the international stage currying favour with tin-pot dictators like Fidel Castro—
—Come to your question.
—traipsing the corridors of power. What we want to get—

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Senator Alston has sought to ask a supplementary question. What he is doing instead is engaging in debate and not framing any question at all. I ask you to bring him to the question, rather than getting into an uncontrolled debate at this stage.

—On the point of order, Mr President: on numerous occasions when points of order have been taken to challenge the relevance of answers being given by ministers you have said that you have to listen to the answer to ascertain whether it is relevant. I put it to you that in this case you have to listen to the one minute of a question so you can ascertain whether a question is being asked or a statement is being made. In other words, you have to give Senator Alston a fair go.
—I have already said to Senator Alston that he should get to the question. I ask him to get to the question.

—We know what we see. What we want to get is an assurance from you, Senator Evans, that you will give away your grandiose international ambitions, get your mind on the job and concentrate on representing Australia's interests, standing up for Australia, not rolling over like a pussy cat and letting yourself be tickled by the French.

—My grandiose international ambitions are a figment of your imagination, Senator Alston. My responsibility and my task are to represent to the best of my ability Australia's national interests right across the whole spectrum of issues: security interests, economic interests and good international citizenship interests. I believe I have done so with credibility and effectiveness. I also believe that it is absolutely crucially important if you are going to be effective and persuasive in the conduct of international relations to be consistent, moderate, balanced and persuasive in the way you do it.
—You are ineffective; that is the problem.

—To be effective. What it is all about is being effective. What it is not about is blowing your bags, having a great ejaculatory outburst and believing you have done something credible. What it is not about is making claims of an extravagant kind and then having an utter unwillingness to follow those through. I have always done that. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I draw the minister's attention to the National Rural Women's Forum which was held on 7 and 8 June in Parliament House. At that meeting delegates from all over Australia developed a national agenda to address key issues for rural women. What action has the minister initiated to ensure that rural women have a greater say in the formulation of rural policy?
—My department, I am pleased to say, was the co-sponsor of this excellent initiative.
—A good conference.

—It was a very good conference, Senator West. Like many of the forum delegates, I am also concerned at the lack of involvement by rural women in the policy making process. Indeed, over the last 18 months I have taken a consistent position on this, particularly in the representations I have made to the industry bodies themselves to redress the situation in terms of their appointments to the many rural organisations across Australia which industry has control of, rather than the government—and with some success.

PARA.TAB: I warmly congratulate the Grains Council of Australia for its recent appointment to a senior position of Linda Botterill, a former ministerial adviser on my staff—sorely missed—and on the staff of the previous minister for primary industry, Simon Crean. I think that primary industry is now recognising the great depth of talent of women around Australia, and this is reflected in this recent appointment by the Grains Council.

We need to increase the participation of women, both to ensure that the issues relevant to them are addressed and addressed adequately, and to improve the quality of rural policy through closer consultation with those who are affected by it. I have already asked my department to put in place initiatives to achieve this aim. As a first step, a rural women's unit has been established in the department. The unit will develop policies and programs to improve the status of rural women and to enhance the role of women in agriculture. It will be headed by a national rural women's coordinator, supported by departmental staff.

The national rural women's coordinator position was advertised widely in the national and regional press. It attracted, I am pleased to say, widespread interest. More than 300 enquiries were received about the position and 81 applications for the position were lodged from all over Australia, including from the Northern Territory. The major rural women's groups, the Country Women's Association, Australian Women in Agriculture and the Foundation for Australian Agricultural Women, participated fully in the selection process.

On the advice of the selection committee, I am pleased to advise the Senate that Ms Helen Board has been appointed as the national rural women's coordinator. She will commence her duties with the department in mid-July. Ms Board has an impressive background in rural and remote community development. She is an effective negotiator and advocate, has demonstrated her ability to take a leadership role in issues at the national level, and has excellent policy and program development skills.

One of the first tasks of the new coordinator and the unit will be to examine the agenda developed by forum delegates and to identify opportunities for action by the department. The rural women's unit will also assist with the portfolio strategy to improve the representation of women on portfolio bodies in line with the government's decision to achieve gender equity on government boards, committees and authorities by the year 2000.

The department has made significant progress in identifying ways to meet this target and I am confident that the current low level of female participation in these bodies will improve. I stress again that industry has an important role to play, considering its role in appointing many of the people to these bodies.

Finally, the department is in the process of establishing a committee on women's issues to advise the secretary on portfolio issues relevant to rural women. The committee will also act as a source of advice to the national rural women's coordinator. I expect that these initiatives will lead to real improvements in both the participation of rural women in the policy making process and better policy outcomes as a result in the long run.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is it true that AQIS was asked to approve and did approve the importation of pilchards for human consumption, but not for use in the marine environment? If so, who applied for the importation; where is the applicant located; how much was applied for; when was the application approved; and how much found its way to human consumption? What work had been done by AQIS before approval to ascertain the diseases carried by both the imported pilchards and the indigenous Australian pilchards? Finally, what knowledge did AQIS have of the immune state of the local population with respect to any imported pilchard diseases?

—The answer to the first part of Senator Coulter's question is no. I am advised that since the Quarantine Act commenced in 1908 the importation of fish and fish products has, with very few exceptions, never been restricted for quarantine concerns. Prior permission to import has not been required and therefore has never been sought or given. Over the years, quarantine authorities have imposed a number of restrictions on the importation of fish in the light of the increasing knowledge of fish disease and developments in the industry.

PARA.TAB: As I told the Senate the other day, I am advised—and our own inquiries seem to confirm this—that there is a great dearth of scientific knowledge on fish, not just in Australia but around the world. But, as that knowledge base has been improving internationally, a number of restrictions have been introduced. For example, quarantine requirements were introduced for oysters in 1935, salmonid fish products in 1975, live fish in 1983, and processed feed for aquaculture in 1990 and 1992, when there were concerns raised about insect infestation of these products and concerns also that other animal ingredients were being mixed into the fish feed products.

In 1992, as I also advised the Senate, AQIS commissioned the BRS to conduct a major review of quarantine policies on the importation of aquatic animals, their products and related materials. This was in response to what have been quite rapid changes, particularly over the last few years, in commercial fisheries and aquaculture. As I advised the Senate a few days ago in response to a question from Senator Boswell, that report should be available by July.

In terms of the last part of Senator Coulter's question, I am advised that a preliminary review of the scientific literature reveals no report of significant infectious disease of pilchards anywhere in the world, as far as can be determined. No specific work has been undertaken on diseases of Australian pilchards. In terms of my own examination of the literature, it does not appear to be the case anywhere else, either. One study was undertaken in Western Australia in the 1980s of a parasite distribution amongst species of fish which included pilchards. There has been no scientific work done on the immune status of pilchards to infectious diseases. This would be impossible without the isolation of infectious disease agents.

It is also relevant to again advise the Senate that, because of the death of large numbers of pilchards off the Australian coast some weeks ago, there has been an intensive scientific investigation into possible causes of those deaths by a special Commonwealth-state task force. I anticipate that an interim report from that task force will be with me shortly. In fact, I hope it will be this week.

Senator Coulter and the Senate may be interested to know that in the last 24 hours the Chief Veterinary Officer of Australia has been informed of significant numbers of pilchard deaths apparently occurring off the north coast of the North Island of New Zealand. Thousands of pilchard deaths apparently have occurred there very recently and it appears from the advice we have received from the New Zealand authorities that those deaths have been related or appear perhaps to be related to what has been a significant and sudden drop in ocean temperatures in that area from about 19 degrees to 13 degrees. We are cooperating and consulting, of course, with the New Zealand authorities about this information to see whether any parallels can be drawn between the deaths there and the deaths here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Minister, firstly, will you tell your colleague Senator Cook that there is a dearth of information in this area of great public importance, namely, the area of diseases which can affect large numbers of Australian animals, not just pilchards, and request that he ensure that there is a great deal more money spent in this area of public research? Secondly, will you use your best endeavours to ensure that this dearth of information, this background information, is filled as rapidly as possible, because this will not be the last occasion on which we will see this sort of occurrence.

—I am sure Senator Cook heard, because he is sitting right here. I am happy to provide you with all the information. I have looked at some of it myself; as well as the advice I have received from the department, I have actually examined the literature. This is not unique to Australia, Senator Coulter. There appears to have been very little research on pilchards anywhere in the world—and they occur in large numbers right around the globe. In fact, it is highly likely that as a result of the work that was commissioned by us in 1992 and which is about to be concluded, we have probably done more work on it to this point than anyone else.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Yesterday the Minister for Industrial Relations announced that the government intends to amend legislation to improve the handling of unfair dismissal applications. Has the minister received representations from small business on this matter? If so, do the amendments foreshadowed by the government take into account the substance of these representations?

—The announcement yesterday by the Minister for Industrial Relations indicated some further amendments to the Industrial Relations Act concerning what is described as unfair dismissals. This is an issue the small business community, through the Small Business Forum, has raised with me on many occasions. As a result, I have been able to have discussions with both the minister, the assistant minister, the Prime Minister and other colleagues. The announcement yesterday by the minister in no way moves away from our principal concern to protect the rights of employees from being unfairly dismissed.

PARA.TAB: But the issue that the small business community has quite rightly raised a number of times in recent months involves the procedural rules for how questions of unfair dismissal are dealt with by the courts. The amendments outlined by Mr Brereton yesterday, particularly those about procedural fairness, will mean that the Industrial Relations Commission will be able to look at the broad aspects of why a particular dismissal has occurred rather than just whether there was procedural fairness.

This was the major issue raised with me and the government on many occasions. It is an important indication that this government has a structural arrangement with the small business community and the Small Business Forum whereby issues of concern to the small business community can be raised and dealt with away from the usual ideological baggage that the opposition brings forward in dealing with the small business community.
What is interesting about the announcement yesterday is that both the president of the ACTU and the chief executives of the ACCI and the MTIA have all indicated that they support these changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —You were wrong in the first place; that is why they support them.

—It is interesting that Senator Vanstone interjects. The ACTU accepted that there needed to be some change. In the context of the negotiation of accord mark 8, it was willing to support these changes. The way that those opposite would go about industrial relations under their present leader would be based on an ideology of the 17th century. There would be a master-servant relationship that abuses the rights of employees and gives them no rights.

PARA.TAB: We believe that the balance we have achieved in this respect is excellent. We also believe that the small business community, through the Small Business Forum, has had a very proper role to play in raising its particular concerns on procedural fairness. That has been dealt with.

Tomorrow, when the next meeting of the Small Business Forum takes place, I am sure that it will welcome the changes announced by the government. It had a constructive role in bringing them to the fore with the government. We responded accordingly, which is an indication of the role that this government has with small business compared with the empty rhetoric from those opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In view of recent criticisms by the Wilson family of the handling by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of the abduction and murder of the Australian David Wilson in Cambodia—

—I understood the family, Senator Kernot. I ask the minister: what measures are being taken generally to assess how the department assists Australians who are travelling overseas and who are in need of government assistance? I cite, for example, the department's handling of such cases as those of David Wilson, Ben Maresh and Rob Bowra, an Australian businessman who is still trapped in the United Arab Emirates. I ask the minister in his answer to advise the Senate as to whether the government will support the inquiry into these matters which has been called by Senator Woods, the chairman of the Senate foreign affairs committee.

—I do not believe there is any need for an inquiry into the government's handling of these matters, although we have absolutely nothing to hide in terms of the way in which we have approached each one of them. In fact, they have been the subject of quite exhaustive examination and cross-examination in Senate estimates committees, and I am always willing to use that occasion to explain fully what we have done. Were an inquiry to be set in train, we would, of course, respond fully and explain exactly what we have done in each of these matters.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty about these matters is, of course, something that is often misunderstood by members of parliament and certainly by the wider community—that there are extreme limitations on Australia's capacity to deal with problems that do afflict Australian citizens abroad when those problems are of a kind which require police investigative action or other effective executive action of that kind. The most you can ever do is make representations to the government in question and, when it comes to police investigations, liaise with the local police authorities and hope that you can persuade them to do whatever is necessary to mount an effective inquiry.

You cannot take it into your own hands and do it. The only context in which that is possible, technically, is for Australian offences which have extraterritorial application; for example, the paedophile laws or laws of that kind which make it an offence for Australians to do certain things while they are, in fact, overseas. Then there is a jurisdictional foundation on which to place an investigative role but, of course, in practice that, too, depends on full cooperation from the local authorities. So the particular problems that you are referring to all basically have had these characteristics.

So far as Mr Bowra is concerned—and it has been a long and ongoing saga and a most unhappy one from his point of view—we have made every representation we can possibly do for him, including most recently in the context of his problem with a passport, which I understand has been resolved or is about to be resolved.

In the case of Ben Maresh, I met with the family a couple of weeks ago and fully explained the limitations that have confronted us in terms of that particular investigation. I have undertaken to the family to have a complete review of all the available material and evidence, including some that was not put before the coroners inquiry, to see whether there is any foundation for going back to the Indonesian authorities and getting them to reopen that investigation.

In the case of David Wilson and Kelly Wilkinson in Cambodia, that was a heart-rending affair for all concerned; and I believe we did, as a government, everything we possibly could and are continuing to do that in an endeavour to bring the killers to justice in both cases and are maintaining constant vigilance, so far as the Cambodian government is concerned, in ensuring that arrest warrants have been issued and there is appropriate follow-up action.

Might I say, in terms of the capacity and performance of Australian consular officers generally in missions overseas, I get far more letters of congratulations and thanks, averaging at least one or two a week, from people who have been impressed and touched by the quality of the service that has been rendered to them—in many cases going above and beyond the call of duty. You never hear about those cases publicly. You only hear about the difficult cases, the heart-rending cases, the ones that go wrong.

I believe we have a good and professional consular service, but there are just some things which are beyond the capacity of any government anywhere in the world to be able to do. You do just have to depend, basically, on the goodwill and the effectiveness of the governments with which you are dealing; and we are in that position, as is every other government in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Evans, where is the harm in agreeing to the inquiry called by Senator Woods? Where is the harm? No harm can come from it—only good, according to what you have just said.

—When you have had a three per cent cut in the running costs of your department, when you have officers who are desperately overstretched in dealing with the enormous and rapidly expanding range of responsibilities and issues that press in upon them, having inquiries for the sake of inquiries, where there is nothing that remains to be put on the public record that has not already been put on the record, when people have the opportunity of pursuing particular matters in the way that you do through the estimates committee process, where you get full cooperation in that process, where you get the sort of cooperation that you personally have had in the particular problems that you have pursued—without any grace in return, I might add, by way of public acknowledgment—I simply do not think that the expenditure of resources is justified.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. How does the minister explain that his initial response to the French government's decision to resume underground nuclear bomb testing at Mururoa Atoll was so totally out of kilter with the outrage felt by the people of Australia and falls in line with a series of failures on his part to take the far more robust view held by Australian people on a series of issues, like East Timor, Cambodia, and now this? Is the minister suggesting that his weak position reflected government policy as distinct from diplomatic niceties?

—The whole point about the conduct of foreign policy is to be as angry as you appropriately can and should be in these cases but to make that anger controlled and productive. You do not conduct foreign policy by putting on an Andrew Peacock angry face. You conduct your foreign policy in a way that is likely to be most productive.

PARA.TAB: I have explained the step-by-step approach that we have adopted so far as the French tests are concerned. I have explained how we have, in fact, followed the injunction of Mr Howard not to fire all the shots in the locker at once but see what the initial response is and then develop a further response based upon that. That is exactly what we have done.

I have explained how, as a matter of practical dealing with other governments, it is always best to frankly acknowledge whatever it is that can be said on the other side of the case rather than pretend that there is nothing at all other than sheer, unmitigated horror, and pretend on the basis of that to be able to make a persuasive case.

There is enough in the French decision to make all of us deeply, genuinely angry and outraged. I have explained how angry I was personally at the breach of faith that I felt was there so far as the NPT negotiations were concerned. I have explained how distressed and disappointed I was at the implications of this for the comprehensive test ban negotiations, a major Australian and worldwide policy objective which, I believe, has been prejudiced by this.

I was distressed, as I said before, by the contemptuous indifference that was shown to our South Pacific island neighbours by the move; that after all these years of anxiety and concern on environmental fronts and with all the unresolved issues about the dangers, not only of accidents but also of leakages, once again that concern was being ignored. I believed, for better or worse, that the best way of dealing with this particular matter was to put those concerns on the record and then to move from there to gradually but inexorably, and with as much effectiveness as possible, engage in a persuasive exercise with the French.

I believe we did that very successfully in France in the sense of very successfully communicating the nature, the intensity, the depth of concern that is felt all around the region. I think that we also had some success in pointing out to the French a number of ways in which they could extract themselves from the morass in which they are now engaged, in particular: firstly, by having a decent negotiating position on the comprehensive test ban treaty; secondly, by committing themselves once and for all to joining the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty and signing the protocols; and, thirdly, by closing Mururoa and making a commitment to do that, hopefully immediately but, if not, on the completion of these eight tests after the 175 they have already conducted there.

Those were the propositions put to them. I think the French government understands the force of those propositions, the utility of them, and I think we made some particular progress because there is a lot of people in the French governmental system, as well as in the French community, who are deeply unhappy with the decision that has been made by the incoming president—deeply unhappy. What we all hope is that this will simply be the last twitch of the Gaullist dinosaur so far as attitudes towards nuclear explosions are concerned. That is what we are hoping to see.

But, as Mr Howard said, you do not fire all your shots at once if you want to be persuasive. You do not behave like a grubby little opportunist, walking around with a wet finger in the air, taking positions that are utterly at odds with the policy positions you have adopted in your entire previous political life. We know where Mr Howard stood, we know where you lot stood on the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty in the mid-1980s. We know the hypocrisy with which you are mounting your mock horror at this stage. We know the extent to which you turned on a sixpence within 24 hours from your initial statements when you thought there was a bit of political mileage in it. (Time expired)

—My question is also addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Can the minister confirm that there is to be a reduction of over 20 per cent in the funding made available to each State under the Commonwealth emergency relief program? Can the minister confirm that this will mean, for example, a cut in funding of over $500,000 to Western Australia? —The emergency relief funding is allocated each year on the basis of a formula that is principally dependent on the number of people on unemployment benefit. Based on those figures this year, as a result of the dramatic fall in the number of people on unemployment benefit, there has been a significant fall in the allocation for emergency relief—from something like over $19 million to $14 million. While I have not got the exact figures for Western Australia, Senator, I have no reason to doubt your figures showing that there has been a drop in Western Australia of the order you say.

PARA.TAB: The most important thing to know is that the formula we have at the moment is based on unemployment figures. That significant drop means that there is a fall in the formula for emergency relief. Importantly, hopefully, that should be a measure too of the fall in the number of people who are approaching agencies looking for assistance for emergency relief. One of the things we hope is that people will, in fact, not keep using emergency relief but, indeed, get steered to or go directly to the payments under social security to assist families in times of difficulty. The ongoing commitment by government for payments for families is much the preferred way to go for families than depending on emergency relief.

The government does recognise that, from time to time, families may have a call on moneys that they simply do not have access to—for example, if a car breaks down, it might be some hundreds of dollars to fix. For a family, that is very critical, but, if you are living on a very tight budget, you may not be able to find that kind of finance. The emergency relief is there to assist families in that kind of cash call.

We are not quite sure who are the people using emergency relief. That is why I am pleased to inform the Senate that I have just approved a considerable grant to ACOSS to do significant research on the people using emergency relief so that we can be much clearer about just what it is that leads people to emergency relief—whether those people come back time and time again; whether they are people who visit emergency relief once and are then assisted into other payments and benefits that our government provides; whether they are working families on low incomes—we have a sense that quite a few families of that sort might sometimes use emergency relief; also, particularly, whether the people providing emergency relief do have the best training and support to assist them in working with families and to encourage them not to depend on emergency relief but to go into the mainstream payments on behalf of families.

Senator, I think the important thing is that within your question there is an understanding that, as there may still be a considerable need for emergency relief, if the formula we have means these cuts are real and perhaps there will still be more call than there is finance for it, we might need to look at that formula for the allocation of emergency relief. We will be able to do it based on good data from the ACOSS research. I think it will put us in a much stronger position to know exactly who uses emergency relief and whether or not our formula does need to be changed.

—I have no personal detailed knowledge of that particular fishery, but I will refer Senator O'Chee's supplementary question to the minister responsible for fisheries.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific region.

SPEECH.PARA: That explanation of Senator Gareth Evans really demonstrates our concern in this matter. Earlier this week when we raised the question of what the Australian government did between the election of the French President and his announcement, when the whole world knew that he was going to announce the resumption of tests, when it was running hot in the international media, when it had been a specifically stated promise in the course of the French elections, what did the Australian government do? The answer we heard in the Senate on that occasion was twofold—the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) had written a simple letter and so had Foreign Minister Evans to the now Prime Minister of France, Monsieur Juppe, formerly the foreign minister.

PARA.TAB: Later in the week Senator Ray had to come in here and say, `No, in actual fact, the letter from Senator Evans didn't refer to the tests at all.' Today Senator Evans got up and said, `I wrote to the Prime Minister raising concern about these tests.' After question time he said that in fact it now seems he did not write to the Prime Minister raising the issue of the test. What a confused state of affairs! It demonstrates and underlines that the Australian government took so little action. At the only time when it had any realistic chance of influencing a change of policy on the part of France, the Australian government did next to nothing. That is the point. It seems that the Australian foreign minister personally took no action at all. I accept what he said; in fact, he is picking up a statement that my leader made. Obviously, in these circumstances you make a graduated response. You do not fire off all your shots at once.

The point is that at the time when there was a chance that the Australian government could have influenced a change, it did not fire off any shots at all. This delegation that Senator Evans led to France is not firing off all your shots. If it was worthwhile doing, why wasn't it done before the public announcement of the French policy? Why didn't Senator Evans take diplomats from the South Pacific, or better still take leaders from the South Pacific, to France to express concern as to what would happen if the French election promise was implemented? It did not occur to him to do so because he was concerned with other matters. That is the point that we are seeking to make. Senator Evans did nothing at the time when he might have influenced a change of direction.

Secondly, when the public announcement was made, what did Senator Evans do? He talked down the decision that France had made. There is only one way that that gets interpreted. We all know diplomatic code. That is interpreted by France and intended to be interpreted as a form protest.

TALK.START.PARA: —A wink and a nod.

—As Senator Alston says, a wink and a nod. Senator Evans was saying, `I am going through the motions, doing what the Australian people would expect me to do but don't take it too seriously.' When Senator Evans was immediately asked about it, he said that he deplores the decision of France. That is fine, on the one hand. On the other hand, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We do acknowledge that the context in which these tests will be taking place is really very different from that in which they have taken place in the past. There are some very clear assurances that they will be limited in number . . .

He goes on and eventually says that the situation is not as bad as it could have been. How else could France have interpreted that other than to say that Australia is not serious about its protest? There is no other way in which that could reasonably be interpreted. That is the whole point. A graduated response, yes, but take it seriously. When Senator Evans had a chance to influence a change of policy he should have done something. When the announcement was made he should have made a vigorous protest, not compromise the situation by almost talking it away before he led this delegation to France. The graduated responses that he has made have been as a reaction of the anger of the Australian people, not as a result of his recognition as to how serious this matter should be treated or his capacity to influence—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was your statement on day one? If you had something here on the record that would be much better.

—Senator Evans's only real explanation today is to attack the opposition because it had a different policy during the days of the Cold War. How inadequate is that response? The opposition is not in judgment here; it is the performance of the minister, and he has been found wanting.

—Well may members of the opposition wave their arms around in anger when, in fact, they have had a pro-nuclear policy ever since the Ranger inquiry in the 1970s. They were the ones who began the uranium mining and the export of uranium. They were the ones who have supported the very industry which lies at the basis of both the civil and military nuclear program. For a short time the government took an ethical position. The Labor Party had a policy of opposing uranium mining and export but it too adopted a very pragmatic position later on and its present position is totally indefensible.

PARA.TAB: What we have had today from Senator Hill is simply more arm waving. He is talking about who did what and when, not what should have been done. That is the important point. I remind the Senate that yesterday, when we raised this matter through seeking a suspension of standing orders, we raised the really important issue of whether Australia should continue to mine and export uranium and, particularly, to send that uranium to France, underpinning the very industry which is now the basis of those nuclear tests in the Pacific. We found that, with the exception of the Greens, this whole Senate—as a body—sat on this side of the chamber and voted against the suspension of standing orders.

Those people did not want to debate the really important issue of what might be done effectively to send a message to France that in things nuclear we totally separate ourselves from what the French are doing and what other nations are now threatening to do—although I see from this morning's newspaper that the US seems to be drawing back from further nuclear tests. That is the issue that should be debated here, not whether the minister took action this week or last week and whether that action was weak—as it was. We accept the opposition's statement that what the minister said was clearly sending a message to France that Australia was not serious about taking significant action against the French.

We stress again that our party since 1977 has consistently taken a position of opposing the mining and export of uranium because of the position we now find ourselves in. The minister may well speak in a moment. He will point to the non-proliferation treaty and other things, but they are bits of paper which have no ability whatsoever—as we see with these tests and as the minister in his reply has indicated—to restrict the use of the uranium that Australia sends to other countries once it has left our shores. There is no ability to control that.

We know that even under the NPT it is possible for a country to make all the hardware for a nuclear weapon, short of actually arming it, go through the processes of giving notice, withdraw from the NPT in six months, put plutonium into the bomb and explode its weapons. There is no protection in the sorts of paper agreements to which the minister has drawn attention on a number of previous occasions.

The issue is what substantive action Australia should take to indicate not only to France, but to the rest of the world, that we will not participate in any way in any part of this nuclear fuel cycle, bearing in mind that there are clear links between the civil and military programs, links which are indicated by the reticence of the Americans to support the sale of Russian reactors to Iran and the concerns we have expressed over the sale of nuclear reactors to North Korea. There are clear links and we should desist from that uranium mining and export.

We have not made the enormous profits predicted back in the 1970s. There has not been the predicted expansion in the mining industry. It is not a great booming industry for Australia and I believe that for very good reasons we should withdraw from that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take note of the inadequacy of the response of Senator Gareth Evans to the question put by Senator Hill. That also applies to Senator Alston's and my questions. I reiterate that the response of this government—and the foreign minister in particular—to the resumption of nuclear testing was totally weak and inadequate. We have to ask: does it really represent foreign policy or is it representing the kind of fancy diplomatic footwork that was described in Senator Evans's answers? It raises the other question of where and how we derive our foreign policy. Senator Evans did not answer my question which asked whether he was aware how out of touch he is with the people of Australia. That is what I would like to mention here.

PARA.TAB: Where does the attitude of the population of Australia come into determining the strength of the stance that is going to be taken by the Australian government and the foreign minister on this issue? Basically, Senator Evans has found himself in the position of defending the indefensible, and we have to ask what was achieved by the fancy diplomatic footwork and the courtesies of international discourse that he described so repetitively and eloquently to us.

I would like to comment on the French news on SBS last Sunday. The news described the New Zealand people as `a little bit nervous' and said that `they seem to have an allergy to the atomic bomb'. However, the foreign minister of France, Herve de Charette, speaking from Canada, reassured us. He said, `My Australian colleague, he understands.' Is that the kind of foreign policy we want to see reflected on the world stage? The achievement that Senator Evans said he made at this delegation in Paris, that the French government will eventually cease after they have done eight more tests, is the same position that the French government took in its initial statement about what it intended to do.

I want to continue with the statements of the French foreign minister on the SBS news on Sunday. Before Senator Evans had even reached Paris, the French foreign minister said, `You don't understand. There are two decisions made by President Chirac and one is much more important than the other. The first is we are just going to have eight little atomic bomb tests in Mururoa Atoll, and the second is that definitivement we will be ceasing in May.' That is no consolation to the people of Australia, New Zealand and the South Pacific. It must not continue.

No one in the region will be happy with the French government's stance, or the stance that has been reflected by this government, until the position of the French government changes so that there will not be a resumption of underground nuclear bomb testing in Mururoa Atoll or by any other country anywhere else in the world. It is a planetary position we hold, and we have to take care of the planet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point that the parliament is making is that the French tests must stop. The criticism of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and of this government is demonstrated by the credibility and the representativeness of Senator Hill's question today, his supplementary question and his motion to take note of the minister's inadequate answer. Even the silence from the minister's own colleagues behind him indicate the criticism from within his own party ranks, let alone the Left caucus of the Labor Party, let alone the eloquent speeches by Senator Chamarette and Senator Coulter.

PARA.TAB: I support entirely Senator Hill's remarks. I reiterate that the Australian public in the last two weeks has been so outraged by the way the Australian government has let down the national interest that it has made this an issue which will hang around the neck of the minister and the government. It is only rarely that foreign policy issues become election issues and I put it to the minister, in reiterating the protest from every part of this chamber, that, for his inadequate answer today, his inadequate action since the election of the new President of France who has declared his intention to renew atomic testing in the South Pacific, the Australian public will hold him and the government accountable.

The minister may well say, `Life is unfair.' He may say that he has been working flat out, had two hours sleep, had six years as foreign minister, achieved enormous gains—with bipartisan support on most issues, such as the NPT conference relevant to this matter, such as pressure for disarmament, such as, with Senator McMullan, pressure on the French with regard to agricultural subsidies in Europe, and so on. Despite all that, when a major mistake is made, this parliament and the people of Australia know it. We require of this minister and this government a more substantial response. There needs to be some mea culpa that there was an opportunity to act and there was no action.

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade happened to meet two weeks ago with the French ambassador. The French are in no doubt about how strongly we feel about this. We have made endlessly clear in very direct talks and representations that I have had, that the Prime Minister has had going back now for the whole period. It was always on the cards that this policy would be changed with a change of government, once President Mitterand, the Socialist President, left office and the Conservatives were in power across the spectrum. One consoling thing about all of this is that the decision has obviously been wrestled with rather than just instantly taken and that it is accompanied by these important qualifications limiting the duration of the tests to May next year, limiting the number to eight and accompanied with a very firm commitment to negotiate and conclude by next year a comprehensive test ban treaty. GE:You've seen the Prime Minister's press release by now, earlier today, announcing the core composition of the delegation from the South Pacific that I will be leading to Paris on Monday, leaving Japan tomorrow for that purpose. The decision to send such a mission follows an initial conversation I had with the French Foreign Minister two nights ago; a long conversation in which I covered all the substantive grounds about objections and raised with him the possibility of such a delegation and urged him to receive it at as short notice as possible. That's been able to come together and I will be leading it as I say.

The object of that delegation is to convey, unequivocally and unambiguously, the distaste and resentment which does exist right around the South Pacific region about the French decision to resume nuclear tests. The arguments that we will be putting to the French Government are essentially threefold, seeking reconsideration of the decision. First, that the decision involves a really quite fundamental breach of faith with all those countries who worked so hard to secure the indefinite extension of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty just a few weeks ago and did so for the reason, among others, that the Nuclear Weapons States said that they would exercise the "utmost restraint" so far as nuclear testing was concerned in the future, until such time as the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty is negotiated. The NPT has, of course, been in existence for twenty years. It is the most important single arms control and disarmament treaty we have, and it is absolutely crucial that its credibility remain intact if its effectiveness is not to be diluted, and that is a very important consideration.

Secondly, we will be arguing, so far as the negotiation of the new Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty is concerned—it doesn't yet exist; it is not in place, there is no legal obligation to stop anyone testing; we have got to try and put that in place that this decision poisons the atmosphere for those negotiations in Geneva which are still at a very sensitive and delicate stage and do involve, among others of course, countries other than the nuclear weapons states themselves. To the extent that they are as upset as we all are by this test resumption decision, it is going to make it that much harder to get a negotiated outcome within the time frame that we are all seeking

Thirdly, we will be arguing that this does involve a really quite serious breach of faith with the countries of the South Pacific who have made as clear as they possibly could their concern about these tests taking place in their own neighbourhood. We have made clear our concerns—particularly the environmental consequences, the dangers that could be obviously be associated with any accident during the context of the tests, and in particular the longer term, really unforeseeable, dangers associated with possible leakage from the underground rock structures, coral structures that are housing the tests. We are concerned that those consequences could occur. And we believe that if the French are as confident as they say they are that there is no risk of accident, there is no long term possibility of this kind of leakage occurring, then why don't they hold the tests on a farm in Provence or down a mine shaft in Picardy.

That is the case that we will be putting. We will be putting it very clearly, very directly and seeking of course a reconsideration of the decision on that basis. There won't be any room for doubts—ifs, buts or maybes—about where Australia or any other South Pacific country stands on this, just as there has never been any room for such doubts in the past.

Q:The other day Senator you said that you didn't think these tests were—I've forgotten the exact words—but the decision to recommence the testing wasn't as bad as what it could have been, yet Australia is now leading a delegation to Paris. What brought about the changes of mind?

GE:The other day I made exactly the same points as I have made today. I notice that Don McKinnon, the New Zealand Foreign Minister (who hasn't been criticised at all so far as I am aware, for the way in which he has made the case) said in a radio interview, about the same time as I was talking to you, that, and I quote "Certainly I don't see this in the same parallel as the late 60s or early 70s—of atmospheric tests or unlimited tests out in front of you": he made that point in various ways, that there were obvious contextual distinctions between then and now. I was simply explaining that that is why our response was a proportionate one, one that was appropriate to the nature of the sin that was being presently committed. But it didn't in any way then, nor does it now, effect the strength of our basic position. We are prepared to acknowledge what has to be acknowledged because that is the role in which you conduct diplomacy, that is the way you are most effective, most persuasive—not by being raucous, and refusing to acknowledge what can be said on the other side of the equation. But having acknowledged that, we keep on coming back to the basic point that these tests do appear to be unnecessary and they do appear to be counter-productive in terms of the major concerns we have about the effectiveness and credibility of the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. —I want to ask a few questions in relation to the answers given by Senator Gareth Evans during question time. The trade-off is not in any way going to strengthen a comprehensive test ban treaty. The trade-off is more likely to put the whole test ban treaty off the rails altogether.

Australia will share that responsibility if the comprehensive test ban treaty goes off the rails. Why? Because everybody is going to look and say, `We don't take this seriously. We're not judging the action in itself. We're judging it in the same way that the government considers it should operate in parliament'—that is, to do trade-offs which are leading to something else, which we all know do not lead to a result. Does that mean Australia guarantees that—no matter what Indonesia does, no matter what other countries do, no matter what areas they may take in towards developing nuclear weapons, no matter how dangerous their program might be in relation to their nuclear power program, no matter what they do—we have to supply uranium if companies in Australia negotiate to do that? TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is this: in the last six years we have had some very unfortunate circumstances where Australians overseas have been in desperate need of assistance because they have been hijacked, held hostage or imprisoned. I refer to 1989 when Miss Jacqueline Hamill was taken hostage by some prisoners in the Philippines and subsequently murdered. I refer to David Wilson who was taken hostage in Cambodia and subsequently murdered. I refer to the case of Robert Bowra, a businessman from Western Australia who was trying to sell Australian-made boats in the Middle East and who had the misfortune to be involved in an accident which resulted in the death of a local citizen. Mr Bowra was subsequently imprisoned for six months. If Robert Bowra had been in Australia he would not have been liable to any criminal sanction at all. There have been complaints about the department's handling of these matters and they cannot go unnoticed.

Dear Mal,
Thank you for your letter of 11 May 1995 concerning the amendment to condition 8108 of the Migration Regulations in Statutory Rule No 38 of 1995.

As you know, regulation 71 of Statutory Rule No 38 of 1995 amends condition 8108 to require that a person must not be employed in Australia by any one employer for more than 3 months without the permission in writing of the Secretary. Condition 8108 is only imposed in relation to subclass 417 (Working Holiday) visas.

The working holiday scheme provides an opportunity for young people to holiday in Australia and supplement their funds through incidental work. Australia has formal working holiday agreements with Canada, the Republic of Ireland, Japan, the Republic of Korea, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands. The agreements enable nationals of those countries who have turned 18, but have not turned 31, to enter Australia as working holiday makers, provided they satisfy all prescribed criteria. Nationals of other countries who have turned 18, but have not turned 26, may also enter as working holiday makers, once again provided they satisfy all prescribed criteria for the grant of the visa.

As the main reason for subclass 417 visa holders being in Australia is to holiday, it is intended that any employment in Australia should be incidental to that purpose. It is considered that, in most cases, working for long periods with one employer would be inconsistent with this policy intent. Accordingly, subclass 417 (Working Holiday) visas are granted subject to condition 8108.

Prior to amendments to the Regulations in September 1994, the equivalent to condition 8108 (ie condition 9217) required that a person must not be employed by any one employer in Australia for more than three months without the permission in writing of the Secretary. It appears that the words "without the permission in writing of the Secretary" were omitted due to a drafting error during the drafting of the September 1994 Regulations. The amendment to condition 8108 accordingly restores the former position.

As condition 8108 is a condition which attaches to a visa, rather than a criterion relating to the grant of a visa, the Secretary's discretion in relation to this condition is not subject to formal merits review. The exercise of this discretion is, however, subject to other accountability measures such as investigation by the Ombudsman.
Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention.
