SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, you can say a lot of things about the Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss. One of the things you cannot say is that he is not a skilful politician. He said yesterday that he did not want Paul Keating or Mickey Mouse in Queensland for the election. He must think Queensland people are living in fantasy land if he thinks that sort of rhetoric is going to fool them into not seeing what his connection is with the federal Labor Party. I see in today's newspapers that he has gone even stronger than that in saying, `We don't want Keating here at any cost.'

PARA.TAB: Goss is simply indulging in the sort of hypocrisy the Labor Party has become renowned for, the hypocrisy of trying to distance himself from Mr Keating and indulging in a bit of good old-fashioned Queensland style Canberra bashing. He thinks that will do him good in the state election coming up. But the Queensland people are not Disneyland type people; they are not in fantasy land as Mr Goss thinks them to be. The people of Queensland understand that the government Mr Goss runs in Queensland is the same sort of high taxing, big spending, big bureaucracy government that we have here in Canberra.

My colleague the Queensland member Mrs Sullivan asked a question in the House of Representatives yesterday. She alerted the parliament of Australia to the fact that state taxes, fees and fines in Queensland have jumped from $2.3 billion in 1989-90, the last year of the term of the previous government, to $4 billion in 1995-96, under the Goss Labor government. That represents a 76 per cent increase in six years.

I do not think that even Senator Sherry's government could match that—a 76 per cent increase in fees, fines and state taxes by the Queensland Labor government in six short years. What a disgraceful effort that has been, affecting those of us who live in Queensland. We are now paying 76 per cent more in taxes, fines and charges than we were when Mr Goss's government came in. That means that I—and every other Queenslander—will pay $1,260 in state taxes in 1995-96, compared with the $790 that I used to pay six years ago in the term of the previous government. That is an increase for me and for every other Queenslander of $470 annually in state taxes, thanks to the state Labor government.

Do you know what the new Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Beazley) said in answer to Mrs Sullivan's question yesterday? He said that the people of Queensland should thank Premier Goss accordingly. Mr Beazley thinks that we Queenslanders should thank Wayne Goss for increasing our taxes by 76 per cent in the last six years.

I think it is important that Queenslanders be alerted to this subterfuge by the Labor Party. You can be assured that in the next few weeks Mr Goss will indulge in a bit more Canberra bashing and he will get stuck into Mr Keating. But you can bet your bottom dollar that he has already checked it out with Mr Keating, and worked out the strategy. If he is at all persuasive, he will get Mr Keating to criticise him, to try to enhance his vote.

All this rhetoric at election time is tremendous and brilliant but what we really have to look at is that when the crunch comes, what does Mr Goss do about the excesses of the Keating government? What about the fuel tax increases that go up automatically now every six months? Do we ever hear a pipsqueak from Mr Goss and the Labor Party in Queensland about Mr Keating—his mate—increasing automatically those petrol taxes every six months?

I have listened to and read quite a lot but I have not heard or seen anything from Mr Goss or Mr DeLacey, his Treasurer, or from anyone else in the Queensland Labor government, about the 12 per cent increase on goods and services in the housing industry. I think they were pretty loud and vocal about the honest GST proposed by the coalition before the last election, but when Mr Keating introduces a goods and services tax on building construction—on housing, kitchens and cabinet making—we do not hear a pipsqueak from them or from Senator Sherry.

This subterfuge of pretending that Queensland and federal Labor are different parties is hypocrisy. What have we heard from the Queensland government about the horrendous way in which unemployment has attacked Queensland, regional Queensland in particular? Youth unemployment in the regions of Queensland is around 35 to 40 per cent. Do we ever hear anything from Mr Goss about that? The number of long-term unemployed in Queensland is up tremendously. It is very high by national standards, yet there is not a word from Mr Goss.

Mr Goss is introducing an electricity line through national parks and a lot of farming properties in the southern border area of Queensland. His mines and energy minister has said, `We are going to put that in, regardless of what the people of Queensland say.' But where is Senator Faulkner in this instance? Where is he jumping up and down and saying, `Hey, you can't do that.' He does not want to offend his mates in the Queensland Labor government.

When we look at the document I referred to in question time today, entitled Drawing the line on poverty: an assessment of poverty and disadvantage in Queensland and commissioned by the Queensland Council of Social Services, we see Queensland is in a parlous state. Today I mentioned just four examples of how people in Queensland cannot get decent access to health services or any help with unemployment in my state which has been run by a Labor government now for six years in conjunction with a federal Labor government that has been in power for some 12 years. Poverty in Queensland is at a tragic level. Nothing is done by the Queensland Labor government and do not expect anything from the crew down here who have really forgotten the little people in Australia.

I do not want to hold up the Senate. I am aware that we are anxious to get on to estimates committees. I just want to conclude by quoting from a speech Mr Keating made to a Labor Party dinner in Brisbane last year. It shows the hypocrisy of the Labor Party. When it suits, coming up to a Queensland election, the parties try to distance themselves from each other. Goss says he does not want Keating there and, as I say, he will indulge in a bit of Keating bashing and Canberra bashing over the next few weeks. But if you really want to know what it is all about, refer to the words of Mr Keating at that Labor Party dinner last year at the Greek Club in Brisbane. This is how Mr Keating finishes:

SPEECH.PARA: So, thanks for having me back on this occasion, it's a long way from the election now but we've got a lot to do yet. And, as we do it I hope you people of the Labor party in Queensland can be proud of this government—
meaning Goss's government—

proud of what we stand for, but, as important as that, know one thing, that we'll all stand together—Commonwealth Labor Government, Queensland Labor Government, Paul Keating and Wayne Goss, our ministers, our party friends and supporters, all of us, together.

There we are. No matter how much in the next few weeks Mr Goss tries to distance himself from Mr Keating, there it is: they all stand together. The sort of federal government in Canberra at the present time is the sort of government that is becoming increasingly obvious in Queensland—there is the same arrogance, the couldn't care less attitude, the we know best attitude. It always reminds me of one of Wayne Goss's promises before the 1989 election. He said, `I want to do to Queensland what John Cain has done for Victoria.' He is succeeding. From being one of the wealthiest states, we continue to go backwards, and the people of Queensland should be aware of that.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, if you had listened to AM this morning, you would be left in no doubt that there is an election in the air—probably in August of this year, maybe a little later, but certainly it is imminent. The Labor Party is running the same tired old line it was running during the campaign in 1983 and, of course, in 1980. What it says in Canberra every time is, `If you vote for the Liberals, you will lose your jobs in the Public Service.'

PARA.TAB: I want to put on record this afternoon the actual facts of what Labor has done to the Public Service, and Canberra in particular, so that people will be able to evaluate the sort of rubbish that the government keeps putting out as the election campaign goes on. As I said, it started the campaign this morning. There have been changes to the Public Service and drops in the number of staff under Labor, and you might say they are justified. The government may be able to explain it. But that is not what I am talking about today. I am talking about what the government says on the one hand and what it actually does on the other. That is what the people of Canberra and the people of Australia generally need to know something about.
The Department of Finance Public Service Staffing Statistics Report 1994 states:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the 1994 calendar year the number of paid permanent and temporary staff in the Australian Public Service totalled 141,700. This figure comprised 124,900 permanent staff (down by 2% over the year) and 16,800 temporary staff (down by 8% cent over the year).
That is a significant drop. The same document goes on to say:
At 31 December 1993, there were 143,100 permanent staff—

That is quite a drop from what it was prior to the last election, when the government ran the campaign that if you voted Liberal, you would lose your job in the Public Service. There were, in fact, 149,035 staff at that time.

PARA.TAB: The government might be able to explain the drop. It might be able to say why it has been cutting away at Public Service numbers, getting rid of more people than it has been employing. But what it says at election time is that we are the ones likely to do that, not it.

Prior to the last election, we had Senator Nick Bolkus boasting on the Matthew Abraham show on 28 April 1992, and again in parliament on 19 September 1992, that staffing numbers in the Department of Administrative Services—that was his department at the time, so he would know—had been decreased from 18,000 to 13,000. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a process that continues and will continue.
In parliament on 14 December 1992 he said:
Over recent years DAS has been reduced from a department with some 18,000 staff to one with some 11,200 staff.
On 17 September 1992 the Canberra Times reported:
The Labor Government intends to retrench a further 2,300 people from DAS over the next two years.

During the same two-year period government business enterprises have reduced their staffing levels by a massive 34,000 people. Under the Labor government at that time—I am talking about 1992—the Department of Administrative Services lost 1,168 staff; the Department of Defence lost 697 staff; and the Australian Taxation Office lost 4,711 staff. Those figures are taken from the Department of Finance Statistical Bulletin of 1991-92. So honourable senators can trace the history of what has happened.

PARA.TAB: It is even more interesting, though, to look at what the Labor Party has moved out of the national capital during the time it has been in government. We could ask a very good question in relation to each one of them as to why it was moved out of Canberra. That has never been satisfactorily explained in relation to any of them. Of course, the cost to taxpayers of doing so also is a matter that taxpayers would be interested in.

I will tell the Senate some of the organisations that have been transferred away from the national capital, not set up somewhere else. The Human Rights Commission was transferred from Canberra to Sydney—at what cost? The Administrative Appeals Tribunal transferred from Canberra to Brisbane—at what cost and for what reason? The Industry Commission transferred to Melbourne; Australian Defence Industries transferred to Sydney. The National Aviation College, which ought by any test to have been established in Canberra, was established in Tasmania for totally political reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good!

—Of course, it has now been transferred from Tasmania—where to, Senator Sherry? You are not game to answer, are you? It has been transferred out of Launceston—at what cost to the people involved and the taxpayers of Australia? The Australia Post national stamp collection was removed from Canberra to Melbourne. In 1989 the government threatened to relocate the Maritime Safety Authority to Newcastle. In the end it had the good sense to change that decision, but only after an enormous amount of lobbying to keep it in Canberra, which is where it should have been and now is.

PARA.TAB: The federal Labor government voted for the Australian National Training Authority to be in Brisbane, rather than in the national capital, where, quite clearly, a national authority of that kind ought to have been based. Why were the CSIRO headquarters moved to Melbourne from Canberra in the December-January 1992-93 period? It was costly, and for what reason? There was also a proposal to transfer the Australian Broadcasting Authority to Sydney, but that was defeated in the end by the pressure of the sense of it staying in Canberra. So, at any whim the government will shift out of Canberra anything it likes. It does so not because it is in the best interests of the organisation, but for some reason of its own. It is in no position to talk about what a Liberal government would do.

The reason this matter has come this week is because Senator Ian Macdonald had a paper and some notes of his own about his own area of responsibility—regional development. In it he referred to the fact that if he was able to persuade his colleagues for the $1 billion or so that he would like to see allocated to regional development—I suspect many of us would too—he would propose that some of that be spent at the coal face, where regional development is necessary. Who could argue with that? This was latched on to by the Labor Party as saying that we would take public servants from Canberra. Not every Commonwealth public servant is located in Canberra. In fact, I think it is only about 26 per cent who are located in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's a hell of a lot in Townsville.

—There are a lot in Townsville. The great departments of state are based here. They are the big policy departments, so of course they would be here. But the others are out in the regions. The Department of Social Security has regional offices in many parts of Australia; they are delivering services to those in receipt of social security, in areas where there are a lot of people in receipt of social security. The Department of Veterans' Affairs has offices in other parts of Australia where they are delivering services to veterans in need of those services. The Commonwealth Employment Service has offices all over Australia where they are delivering services to people who are unemployed. In regional development, if the government were spend

SPEECH.PARA: ing money on it, it would have public servants based in the areas in which it was spending the money and where it was needed to deliver those services.

PARA.TAB: There are other service departments out and about in the community. But no, the Labor Party just latches on to this one little thing to try to persuade people that if we were in government the Public Service would be attacked. I can assure you, it would not. We are very conscious of the need for a responsible, efficient, competent public service. The number of Commonwealth public servants in Canberra, in the national capital, would probably remain at about 26 per cent of the total number of public servants.

I thought it was worth running over some of the figures today. There are others but that is about all I can fit in in the 10 minutes allowed for an adjournment speech. I have done so to remind the people of Canberra not to be misled by Labor's propaganda.
